qas.question: What is the name of the most commonly seen salamander?
What are the frogs and toads the largest class of?
What tends to detract from the nutrient cycle of the forest?
What consumes the salamanders and amphibians?
What are species of salamanders called as a group?

context: Of great importance are the many species of salamanders and, in particular, the lungless species (<b4_0>Family Plethodontidae<b4_0/>) that live in great abundance concealed by leaves and debris, on the forest floor. Most frequently seen, however, is the <b0_0>eastern or red-spotted newt<b0_0/> (Notophthalmus viridescens), whose terrestrial eft form is often encountered on the open, dry forest floor. It has been estimated that salamanders represent the largest class of <b1_0>animal biomass<b1_0/> in the Appalachian forests. Frogs and toads are of lesser diversity and abundance, but the wood frog (Rana sylvatica) is, like the eft, commonly encountered on the dry forest floor, while a number of species of small frogs, such as spring peepers (Pseudacris crucifer), enliven the forest with their calls. <b2_0>Salamanders and other amphibians<b2_0/> contribute greatly to nutrient cycling through their consumption of <b3_0>small life forms<b3_0/> on the forest floor and in aquatic habitats.
